body_content.explanation: the strings with knots in them that are along the edge of a large white, or white and blue, shawl (= a large piece of cloth) that Jewish men and boys wear over their head and neck when praying:
examples: The Torah requires that followers of the Jewish religion wear tzitzit, or fringes, on their garments.
On each of the four corners of the tallit katan is a hole through which the tzitzit strings are threaded and tied.

body_content.explanation: a white, or white and blue, shawl (= a large piece of cloth) with strings along the edge, that some Jewish men and boys wear under their outer clothes in the daytime:
examples: He was wearing a fringed garment under his shirt, known as a tzitzit.
We wear a little poncho called a tzitzit, or tallit katan (“small tallit”), which fits neatly under a shirt.
